de.uos.nbp.senhance
Interface EventSource

public interface EventSource

An EventSource is a class that will acquire (in the case of physical devices) or generate (in the case of, for example, simulators) data events. An EventSource needs an EventSink as a destination for the events. EventSources have a defined set of states according to the state machine documented in the wiki, and a set of EventSource.UIEvents which inform the UI of user-relevant occurrences. EventSources effectively have 3 outputs:

  1. EventLogger - only one, this is where the data gets sent to be preserved for later.
  2. EventSink(s) - potentially multiple, these modules consume the data as it comes in.
  3. Handler - this is the UI handler that can be sent certain messages relevant for the user.

Author:
rmuil@uos.de

Method Detail

attachLogger

void attachLogger(EventLogger eventLogger)
Attaches an eventLogger to this source. The source should then prepare the eventlogger appropriately. Without a call to this function, the event logger will not be attached and the data will not be persisted.

Parameters:
eventLogger - if this is given, it will be used to persist the data

attachSink

void attachSink(EventSink eventSink)
This function attaches an event sink to this source. Sinks are where the data goes.

Parameters:
eventSink - the EventSink to be attached to this source.

detachSink

void detachSink(EventSink sinkToDetach)
Removes a previously attached event sink from this source.

Parameters:
sinkToDetach -

attachUIHandler

void attachUIHandler(Handler handler,
                     int eventSourceID)
This allows the a handler to be attached to the EventSource so that messages can be passed back, presumably to the user interfaces. The types of messages that get sent are those relevant to the user - things like metrics, state changes etc. The eventSourceID should be generated by the calling class and the implementation of the EventSource should include this id in every message sent to the handler. This allows the handler to determine from where the message comes. As far as I know, the handler structure itself doesn't have a mechanism to determine message origin and so if there are multiple sources (likely) then state changes, for example would be all mixed up by the user interface without this id. All messages back to the handler are expected to contain: + what - a value corresponding to a UIEvent. + arg1 - the eventSourceID that was passed in attachUIHandler + arg2 - [optional] an argument that may be appropriate for the particular UIEvent + bundle - [optional] extended arguments that may be appropriate for the particular UIEvent

Parameters:
handler - the Handler to send messages back to the UI Activity.
eventSourceID - this identifies this event source to the receiving handler.

detachUIHandler

void detachUIHandler(Handler handler)
Detaches the handler from this event source.

Parameters:
handler -

connect

void connect(String address)
Initiates a connection to the remote device specified by address.

Parameters:
address - the address of the underlying event generator device. The form of this depends on the particular implementation (is typically a MAC address).
